figures.description: Graph with vertical axis labeled PV and horizontal axis labeled P, showing several curves/lines labeled K, L, M, N. Used in Question 5.
Graph of number of moles of solute (y-axis) versus temperature in °C (x-axis), rising roughly linearly from about 10°C to 60°C. Used in Question 11.
Reaction energy profile diagram (Energy vs Reaction coordinate) with a hump; X is a vertical measure from reactants level to the top of the hump. Used in Question 27.
Curve of rate of reaction versus reaction time showing a rapid decrease then leveling off. Used in Question 28.
Structure with central carbon attached to CH3 (left), COOH (right), H (top), and OH (bottom). Used in Question 42.
Displayed structure of a carbon chain showing an -OH substituent and chlorine substituent(s). Used in Question 46.

questions.question: Which question Paper Type of Chemistry is given to you?
questions.explanation: The page header clearly states "PAPER TYPE: B".

questions.question: What is the concentration of a solution containing 2g of NaOH in 100cm3 of the solution? [Na = 23, O = 16, H = 1]
questions.explanation: Molar mass of NaOH = 23 + 16 + 1 = 40 g/mol. Moles in 2 g = 2/40 = 0.05 mol. Volume 100 cm3 = 0.1 dm3. Concentration = 0.05/0.1 = 0.50 mol dm-3; however the option list in the image includes 0.50 as B and 0.40 as A. Using the given data, the correct value is 0.50 mol dm-3, so the correct option is B.

questions.question: Which of the following properties is NOT peculiar to matter?

options.text: kinetic energy of particles increases from solid to gas
Random motion of particles increases from liquid to gas
Orderliness of particles increases from gas to liquid
Random motion of particles increases from gas to solid

questions.explanation: Random motion is greatest in gases and least in solids. Moving from gas to solid, random motion decreases, not increases.

questions.question: The principle of column chromatography is based on the ability of the constituents to

options.text: move at different speeds in the column
dissolve in each other in the column
react with the solvent in the column
react with each other in the column

questions.explanation: Column chromatography separates components because they partition differently between stationary and mobile phases, so they travel through the column at different rates.

questions.question: From the diagram above, an ideal can be represented by
questions.explanation: For an ideal gas at constant temperature, PV is constant and does not change with pressure, so a horizontal line on a PV (y) vs P (x) graph represents ideal behavior. In the diagram, the horizontal line is labeled N.

questions.question: Which of the following questions is correct about the periodic table?

options.text: The non-metallic properties of the elements tend to decrease across each period
The valence electrons of the elements increase progressively across the period
Elements in the same group have the same number of electron shells
Elements in the same period have the number of valence electrons

questions.explanation: Across a period, atomic number increases and electrons are added to the same outer shell, so the number of valence electrons increases progressively. (Non-metallic character generally increases across a period, so A is wrong; same group means same valence electrons not shells, so C is wrong; same period means same number of shells, so D is wrong.)

questions.question: The relative atomic mass of a naturally occurring lithium consisting of 90% Li and 10% Li is
questions.explanation: Natural lithium is a mixture of isotopes with mass numbers 7 and 6. Weighted average = (0.90×7) + (0.10×6) = 6.3 + 0.6 = 6.9.

questions.question: An isotope has an atomic number of 15 and a mass number of 31. The number of protons it contains is
questions.explanation: Atomic number equals the number of protons. Therefore it contains 15 protons.

questions.question: The molecular lattice of iodine is held together by
questions.explanation: Solid iodine consists of I2 molecules; the molecules are held together in the crystal by weak intermolecular forces (London dispersion/van der Waals forces).

questions.question: The arrangement of particles in crystal lattices can be studied using
questions.explanation: X-ray diffraction is used to determine crystal lattice structures because X-ray wavelengths are comparable to atomic spacings in crystals.

questions.question: From the diagram above, find the amount of solute deposited when 200 cm3 of the solution is cooled from 55°C to 40°C
questions.explanation: Reading from the graph: at 55°C the solubility is about 7×10^-2 mol per 10 cm3 of solution, and at 40°C it is about 6.5×10^-2 mol per 10 cm3. Decrease ≈ 0.5×10^-2 mol per 10 cm3 = 0.005 mol per 100 cm3. For 200 cm3, deposited = 2×0.005 = 0.01 mol.

questions.question: The importance of sodium aluminate (III) in the treatment of water is to
questions.explanation: Sodium aluminate produces gelatinous aluminium hydroxide in water which acts as a flocculant, coagulating suspended particles so they can settle.

questions.question: What type of bond exits between an element X with atomic number 12 and Y with atomic number 17?
questions.explanation: Atomic number 12 is magnesium (a metal) and 17 is chlorine (a non-metal). Magnesium transfers electrons to chlorine forming an ionic (electrovalent) bond, e.g., MgCl2.

questions.question: Hardness of water is mainly due to the presence of

options.text: calcium chloride or sodium chloride salts

questions.explanation: Hardness is caused mainly by dissolved calcium and magnesium salts. Temporary hardness is linked to hydrogencarbonates (related to carbonates), while permanent hardness is due to sulphates/chlorides. Option B best matches the common calcium salts responsible.

questions.question: A suitable solvent for iodine and nephthalene is
questions.explanation: Iodine and naphthalene are non-polar substances, so they dissolve best in non-polar organic solvents such as benzene.

questions.question: Which of the following noble gases is commonly found in the atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Argon is present in air at about 0.93% by volume, far more abundant than neon, helium, or xenon.

questions.question: N2O4(g) ⇌ 2NO2(g) ΔH = +ve. In the reaction above, an increase in temperature will

options.text: increase the value of the equilibrium constant
decreases the value of the equilibrium constant
shift the equilibrium to the left

questions.explanation: ΔH is positive, so the forward reaction is endothermic. Increasing temperature favors the forward reaction, increasing K and shifting equilibrium toward NO2.

questions.question: CH3COOH(aq) + OH-(aq) ⇌ CH3COO-(aq) + H2O(l). In the reaction above, CH3COO-(aq) is
questions.explanation: CH3COOH donates a proton; after losing H+ it becomes CH3COO-, which is the conjugate base of ethanoic acid.

questions.question: How many cations will be produced from a solution of potassium aluminium tetraoxosulphate (VI)?
questions.explanation: Potash alum contains two types of positive ions in solution: K+ and Al3+. Therefore the number of cations produced (types of cations) is 2.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an alkali?
questions.explanation: An alkali is a base that dissolves in water to give OH- appreciably. NaOH and Ca(OH)2 are alkalies; NH3 forms OH- in water. Mg(OH)2 is very sparingly soluble and is typically not regarded as an alkali in this context.

questions.question: An effect of thermal pollution on water bodies is that the

options.text: level of oxides of nitrogen increase

questions.explanation: Raising water temperature decreases dissolved oxygen solubility and can increase biological oxygen demand, so dissolved oxygen level falls.

questions.question: Which of the following is a deliquescent compound?
questions.explanation: Calcium chloride absorbs moisture from air and can dissolve in the absorbed water, which is deliquescence.

questions.question: A chemical reaction which the hydration energy is greater than the lattice energy is referred to as
questions.explanation: If hydration energy released exceeds lattice energy required to separate ions, net energy is released overall, making the process exothermic.

questions.question: The function of zinc electrode in a galvanic cell is that it
questions.explanation: In a typical galvanic cell (e.g., Daniell cell), zinc is oxidized at the anode: Zn → Zn2+ + 2e-. Thus it produces (supplies) electrons to the external circuit.

questions.question: CH4(g) + Cl2(g) → CH3Cl(s) + HCl(g). The major factor that influence the rate of the reaction above is
questions.explanation: Chlorination of methane is a photochemical free-radical substitution initiated by UV light, so light intensity is the key factor affecting the rate.

questions.question: The condition required for corrosion to take place is the presence of
questions.explanation: Rusting of iron requires both oxygen and water; carbon dioxide may speed it up but is not essential.

questions.question: In the diagram above, X is the
questions.explanation: X marks the energy difference from the reactants level up to the peak of the energy barrier, which is the activation energy.

questions.question: The diagram above best illustrates the effect of decrease in
questions.explanation: As reaction proceeds, reactants are used up so concentration falls, causing the rate to decrease with time and then level off near completion.

questions.question: MnO4-(aq) + Y + 5Fe2+(aq) → Mn2+(aq) + 5Fe3+(aq) + 4H2O(l). In the equation above, Y is
questions.explanation: In acidic medium, permanganate reduction is: MnO4- + 8H+ + 5e- → Mn2+ + 4H2O. Here Fe2+ supplies 5e-, so Y must be 8H+.

questions.question: Given that M is the mass of a substance deposited during electrolysis and Q is the quantity of electricity consumed, then Faraday's first law can be written as [Electrochemical equivalent]
questions.explanation: Faraday’s first law: mass deposited is directly proportional to charge passed, M ∝ Q. With electrochemical equivalent E as the proportionality constant, M = EQ.

questions.question: The impurities formed during the laboratory preparation of chlorine gas are removed by
questions.explanation: During lab preparation of chlorine, hydrogen chloride gas is a common impurity; passing the gas through water removes HCl because it is highly soluble, while chlorine is only slightly soluble.

questions.question: The effect of the presence of impurities such as carbon and sulphur on iron is that they
questions.explanation: Impurities generally disrupt the metal lattice and tend to lower the melting point of metals/alloys compared with very pure iron.

questions.question: A few drops of concentrated HNO3 is added to an unknown solution and boiled for a while. If this produces a brown solution, the cation present is likely to be
questions.explanation: Concentrated nitric acid oxidizes copper metal/compounds producing Cu2+ (blue) and NO2 (brown fumes). A persistent brown coloration in solution is most consistent with copper(II) nitrate solution darkened by dissolved NO2/strong oxidation conditions; among the options, Cu2+ best fits the nitric-acid test context.

questions.question: The bleaching action of chlorine gas is effective due to the presence of
questions.explanation: Chlorine bleaches in moist conditions: it reacts with water to form hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which releases nascent oxygen/acts as an oxidizing agent that destroys dyes.

questions.question: In the laboratory preparation of oxygen, dried oxygen is usually collected over
questions.explanation: To collect a dry gas, you avoid water. Mercury is a liquid over which gases can be collected without introducing moisture; CaCl2 is a drying agent, not a collecting liquid.

questions.question: The property of concentrated H2SO4 that makes it suitable for preparing HNO3 is its
questions.explanation: Concentrated H2SO4 is a strong dehydrating agent and displaces HNO3 from nitrates (it removes water and is non-volatile relative to nitric acid).

questions.question: Bronze is preferred to copper in the making of medals because it
questions.explanation: Bronze (an alloy, mainly Cu and Sn) is harder/stronger and more wear-resistant than pure copper, making it better for durable medals.

questions.question: The constituents of baking powder that makes the dough to rise is
questions.explanation: Sodium hydrogencarbonate releases CO2 (on heating and/or with acid), which forms bubbles that expand the dough.

questions.question: Which of the following compound is used as a gaseous fuel?
questions.explanation: Butane (CH3CH2CH2CH3) is commonly used as a gaseous fuel (LPG component). The alcohol and carboxylic acid options are not typical gaseous fuels.

questions.question: The ability of carbon to form long chains is referred to as
questions.explanation: Catenation is the self-linking property of an element (especially carbon) to form chains and rings through covalent bonds.

questions.question: Which of the following compounds will undergo polymerization reaction?
questions.explanation: Addition polymerization occurs readily in alkenes due to the C=C double bond. Ethene (C2H4) polymerizes to poly(ethene).

questions.question: The compound above exhibits
questions.explanation: The central carbon is attached to four different groups (H, OH, CH3, COOH), making it a chiral center; such compounds can exist as non-superimposable mirror images (optical isomerism).

questions.question: An organic compound has an empirical formula CH2O and vapour density of 45. What is the molecular formula? [C = 12, H = 1, O = 16]
questions.explanation: Vapour density = 45 implies molar mass = 2×45 = 90. Empirical formula mass of CH2O = 12 + 2 + 16 = 30. Multiplier = 90/30 = 3, so molecular formula = (CH2O)3 = C3H6O3, which is option C.

questions.question: C6H12O6 → 2C2H5OH + 2CO2 + energy (zymase, 25°C). The reaction above represented by the equation above is useful in the production of
questions.explanation: This is fermentation of glucose by enzymes (zymase) producing ethanol and carbon dioxide.

questions.question: The number of isomers that can be obtained from C4H10 is
questions.explanation: C4H10 has two structural isomers: n-butane and 2-methylpropane (isobutane).

questions.question: The functional groups present in the compound above are
questions.explanation: The displayed structure shows an -OH substituent (hydroxyl group) and chlorine atom(s) attached to carbon (chloro/halo substituent). Option B states both explicitly.

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary amine?
questions.explanation: A primary amine has the form RNH2. CH3NH2 (methylamine) fits. (CH3)2NH is secondary, (CH3)3N is tertiary, and CH3CONH2 is an amide not an amine.

questions.question: Two organic compounds K and L were treated with a few drops of Fehling's solutions respectively. K formed a brick red precipitate while L remains unaffected. The compound K is an
questions.explanation: Fehling’s solution is reduced by aldehydes (alkanals) to give a brick-red precipitate of Cu2O; ketones, alkanes, and alkanols do not give this test.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about 2-methylpropane and butane

options.text: They are members of the same homologous series
They have the same boiling point
They have different number of carbon atoms
They have the same chemical properties

questions.explanation: 2-methylpropane and butane are structural isomers with the same molecular formula (C4H10) and both are alkanes, so they belong to the same homologous series.

questions.question: CH3COOH + C2H5OH → CH3COOC2H5 + H2O (conc H2SO4). The reaction above is best described as
questions.explanation: A carboxylic acid reacting with an alcohol in the presence of concentrated H2SO4 to form an ester and water is esterification.
